senses.definition: to happen faster or earlier; to make something happen faster or earlier

examples.x: Inflation continues to accelerate.

senses.definition: to start to go faster

examples.x: The runners accelerated smoothly around the bend.

senses.definition: an increase in how fast something happens

examples.x: an acceleration in the rate of economic growth

senses.definition: the rate at which a vehicle increases speed

examples.x: a car with good acceleration
acceleration from 0–60 mph in 11.2 seconds
This model has the best acceleration of any available sports car.

senses.definition: the rate at which the velocity (= speed in a particular direction) of an object changes

examples.x: acceleration caused by gravity

senses.definition: to be the explanation or cause of something

examples.x: The poor weather may have accounted for the small crowd.

senses.definition: to give an explanation of something

examples.x: How do you account for the show's success?

senses.definition: to be a particular amount or part of something

examples.x: The Japanese market accounts for 35 per cent of the company's revenue.

senses.definition: the fact of something increasing over a period of time

senses.definition: a sum or money or a debt that has been allowed to grow over a period of time

senses.definition: to increase over a period of time

senses.definition: to allow a sum of money or debts to grow over a period of time

senses.definition: to gradually get more and more of something over a period of time collect

senses.definition: to gradually increase in number or quantity over a period of time

senses.definition: the process of gradually increasing or getting more and more of something over a period of time

senses.definition: an amount of something that has gradually increased over a period of time

examples.x: an accumulation of toxic chemicals

senses.definition: growing by increasing gradually

examples.x: the accumulative effects of pollution

senses.definition: to make a total amount of something

examples.x: The numbers add up to exactly 100.

senses.definition: to lead to a particular result; to show something

examples.x: These clues don't really add up to very much (= give us very little information).

senses.definition: progress or a development in a particular activity or area of understanding

major advances in the field of physics
an advance on the existing techniques

senses.definition: the forward movement of a group of people, especially armed forces declare/​make/​wage

enemy advances

senses.definition: money paid for work before it has been done or money paid earlier than expected

senses.definition: an increase in the price or value of something

examples.x: Share prices showed significant advances.

senses.definition: to help something to succeed

senses.definition: to give somebody money before the time it would usually be paid

senses.definition: to suggest an idea, a theory or a plan for other people to discuss

senses.definition: to change the time or date of an event so that it takes place earlier

senses.definition: to increase in price or amount

senses.definition: the process of making something better

senses.definition: to recognize the good qualities of somebody/something

senses.definition: pleasure that you have when you recognize and enjoy the good qualities of somebody/something

senses.definition: the feeling of being grateful for something

senses.definition: increase in value over a period of time

senses.definition: a piece of writing or a speech in which the strengths and weaknesses of somebody/something, especially an artist or a work of art, are discussed and judged

senses.definition: to begin to exist or develop

senses.definition: to get out of bed; to stand up

senses.definition: to come together to protest about something or to fight for something

examples.x: The peasants arose against their masters.

senses.definition: to gradually start to be seen as you move towards it
the part of the body at the end of the arm, including the fingers and thumb feel

senses.definition: using the hand or number of hands mentioned

senses.definition: help in doing something

examples.x: The neighbours are always willing to lend a hand.

senses.definition: a part of a clock or watch that points to the numbers
a person who does physical work on a farm or in a factory

senses.definition: a sailor on a ship

senses.definition: by a person rather than a machine

senses.definition: a particular style of writing

senses.definition: to increase the amount, value, size, etc. of something

senses.definition: increasing in regular amounts

examples.x: incremental costs
Guy wires attach to the pole at various incremental heights.

senses.definition: in regular increases, amounts or stages

examples.x: The work progresses incrementally.

senses.definition: happening not as the main aim, cause or result of a particular action, but in addition to it

examples.x: the indirect effects of the war
to find something out by indirect methods
The building collapsed as an indirect result of the heavy rain.

senses.definition: not done directly; done through somebody/something else

examples.x: territories under the indirect control of the British

senses.definition: avoiding saying something in a clear and obvious way

examples.x: The comment was an indirect attack on the prime minister.

senses.definition: not going in a straight line

examples.x: an indirect route

senses.definition: not as the main aim, cause or result of something, but in addition to it; not in a direct line or manner

examples.x: The new law will affect us all, directly or indirectly.

senses.definition: in a way that is not clear or obvious

examples.x: He was referring indirectly to his predecessor as president.

senses.definition: to persuade or influence somebody to do something

examples.x: Nothing would induce me to take the job.

senses.definition: to cause something

examples.x: drugs that induce sleep

senses.definition: to make a woman start giving birth to her baby by giving her special drugs; to make a baby start being born by giving the mother special drugs

examples.x: an induced labour

senses.definition: not achieving what you want to achieve; not having any effect in-

examples.x: The new drug was ineffective.

senses.definition: in a way that does not produce the intended result or a successful result

examples.x: the ineffectiveness of the standard drugs in treating this illness

senses.definition: without the ability to achieve much; weak; not achieving what you want to in-

examples.x: He plays the role of a blustering and ineffectual teacher.

senses.definition: without achieving much or the intended result; in a weak way
to make something start or happen, usually something official

examples.x: The government has instigated a programme of economic reform.

senses.definition: to cause something bad to happen

examples.x: They were accused of instigating violence.

senses.definition: the act of causing something to begin or happen

examples.x: An appeal fund was launched at the instigation of the President.

senses.definition: a person who causes something to happen, especially something bad

examples.x: the instigators of the riots

senses.definition: to move quickly off the ground or away from a surface by pushing yourself with your legs and feet

examples.x: ‘Quick, jump!’ he shouted.

senses.definition: to move quickly and suddenly

examples.x: He jumped to his feet when they called his name.

senses.definition: to make a sudden movement because of surprise, fear or excitement

examples.x: A loud bang made me jump.

examples.x: Prices jumped by 60% last year.

senses.definition: to leave out something and pass to a further point or stage

senses.definition: to move suddenly and unexpectedly, especially out of the correct position

examples.x: The needle jumped across the dial.

senses.definition: to attack somebody suddenly

examples.x: The thieves jumped him in a dark alleyway.

senses.definition: to get on a vehicle very quickly, especially in a way that is dangerous or illegal

examples.x: to jump a train

senses.definition: to start the engine of a car by connecting the battery to the battery of another car with jump leads
to put a lot of energy into starting a process or an activity or into making it start more quickly
to be very lively

examples.x: The club's jumping tonight.

senses.definition: an act of jumping

examples.x: to do a parachute jump
a jump of over six metres

senses.definition: a barrier like a narrow fence that a horse or a runner has to jump over in a race or competition

examples.x: The horse fell at the last jump.

senses.definition: a sudden increase in amount, price or value

examples.x: unusually large price jumps

senses.definition: a large or sudden change

senses.definition: a sudden movement caused by shock or surprise

examples.x: I sat up with a jump.

senses.definition: to go with or in front of a person or an animal to show the way or to make them go in the right direction take

senses.definition: to connect one object or place to another

senses.definition: to go in a particular direction or to a particular place lead

examples.x: A path led down the hill.

senses.definition: to have a particular type of life

examples.x: We lead a very quiet life.

senses.definition: to cause a process to start

examples.x: The recent economic recovery was almost entirely led by exports.

senses.definition: to play first; to play something as your first card

examples.x: It's your turn to lead.

senses.definition: to jump high or a long way

senses.definition: to move or do something suddenly and quickly

examples.x: She leapt out of bed.

senses.definition: to increase suddenly and by a large amount

senses.definition: a long or high jump

examples.x: a leap of six metres

senses.definition: a sudden large increase in something

examples.x: a leap in prices/profits

senses.definition: a sudden change from one thing to another; very fast progress with something

examples.x: Few people successfully make the leap from television to the movies.

senses.definition: having such a big effect that it changes somebody's life

senses.definition: to reduce something or to become less in value, quality, etc.

senses.definition: to make something happen or appear

senses.definition: to breed (= keep and produce young from) particular farm animals; to grow particular crops

senses.definition: to end the limits on somebody/something

senses.definition: to contact somebody and speak to them by radio or phone

senses.definition: to make somebody who has died come to life again

senses.definition: to make a higher bet than another player in a card game

senses.definition: to multiply an amount by itself a particular number of times

senses.definition: to build something

senses.definition: to create a document such as an invoice or a petition

senses.definition: opposition to social or political progress or change

senses.definition: showing a reaction or response

senses.definition: tending to show chemical change when mixed with another substance

senses.definition: in a way that has a particular meaning

examples.x: Significantly, he did not deny that there might be an election.
Perhaps significantly, many of their illegal activities were not considered as crime.

senses.definition: in a way that has a special or secret meaning

examples.x: She paused significantly before she answered.

senses.definition: to go down below the surface or towards the bottom of a liquid or soft substance

examples.x: The ship sank to the bottom of the sea.
The submarine sank after an explosion.
We're sinking!
The wheels started to sink into the mud.
The little boat sank beneath the waves.

senses.definition: to damage a boat or ship so that it goes below the surface of the sea, etc.

examples.x: The battleship was sunk by a torpedo.
Bombs sank all four carriers.
Five brothers all died when their ship was sunk.

senses.definition: to move downwards, especially by falling or sitting down

examples.x: I sank into an armchair.
She sank back into her seat, exhausted.
The old man had sunk to his knees.

senses.definition: to move slowly downwards

examples.x: The sun was sinking in the west.
The sun had sunk below the horizon.
The foundations of the building are starting to sink.

senses.definition: to decrease in amount, volume, strength, etc.

examples.x: The pound has sunk to its lowest recorded level against the dollar.
He is clearly sinking fast (= getting weaker quickly and will soon die).

senses.definition: to become quieter

examples.x: Her voice sank to a whisper.

senses.definition: to make a deep hole in the ground

examples.x: to sink a well/shaft/mine

senses.definition: to place something in the ground by digging

examples.x: to sink a post into the ground

senses.definition: to prevent somebody or somebody’s plans from succeeding

examples.x: I think I've just sunk my chances of getting the job.
If the car breaks down, we'll be sunk (= have serious problems).

senses.definition: to hit a ball into a hole in golf or snooker

examples.x: He sank a 12-foot putt to win the match.

senses.definition: to drink something quickly, especially a large amount of alcohol

examples.x: They sank three pints each in 10 minutes.

senses.definition: to lay eggs
to cause something to develop or be produced

examples.x: The band's album spawned a string of hit singles.

senses.definition: to appear or be created

examples.x: Attackers were spawning from all kinds of unexpected places.
I upgraded the city to spawn a giant.

senses.definition: a thin object with a sharp point, especially a pointed piece of metal, wood, etc.

examples.x: a row of iron spikes on a wall
Her hair stood up in spikes.

senses.definition: a metal point attached to the sole of a sports shoe to prevent you from slipping while running
shoes fitted with these metal spikes, used for running

examples.x: a pair of spikes

senses.definition: a long pointed group of flowers that grow together on a single stem
a sudden large increase in something

examples.x: a spike in oil prices

senses.definition: to push a sharp piece of metal, wood, etc. into somebody/something; to injure something on a sharp point
to add alcohol, poison or a drug to somebody’s drink or food without them knowing

examples.x: He gave her a drink spiked with tranquillizers.
Her words were spiked with malice.
She suspected that her drink had been spiked.

senses.definition: to reject something that a person has written or said; to prevent something from happening or being made public

examples.x: The article was spiked for fear of legal action against the newspaper.

senses.definition: to rise quickly and reach a high value

examples.x: The US dollar spiked to a three-month high.

senses.definition: a shape or design, consisting of a continuous curved line that winds around a central point, with each curve further away from the centre

examples.x: The birds circled in a slow spiral above the house.
A spiral of smoke rose from the chimney.

senses.definition: a continuous harmful increase or decrease in something, that gradually gets faster and faster

examples.x: How can we halt the destructive spiral of violence in the inner cities?
measures to control the inflationary spiral
the upward/downward spiral of sales
the vicious spiral of rising wages and prices

senses.definition: to move in continuous circles, going upwards or downwards

examples.x: Smoke spiralled into the sky.
The plane spiralled down to the ground.

senses.definition: to increase rapidly

examples.x: the spiralling cost of healthcare
Prices are spiralling out of control.

senses.definition: to decrease rapidly

examples.x: Shares in the company continued to spiral downwards.

senses.definition: to decrease rapidly

examples.x: Shares in the company continued to spiral downwards.

senses.definition: to decrease rapidly

examples.x: Shares in the company continued to spiral downwards.

senses.definition: to be the result of something

examples.x: Most people’s insecurities stem from something that happened in their childhood.

senses.definition: a sudden increase of a strong feeling

examples.x: She felt a sudden surge of anger.
a surge of excitement

senses.definition: a sudden increase in the amount or number of something

examples.x: a surge in consumer spending
We are having trouble keeping up with the recent surge in demand.
A last-minute surge in ticket sales saved the show from closure.
After an initial surge of interest, there has been little call for our services.

senses.definition: a sudden, strong movement forward or upwards

examples.x: a tidal surge
A surge of people poured through the gates.
Police struggled to control the sudden surge forward by the demonstrators.

senses.definition: a sudden increase in the flow of electrical power through a system

examples.x: An electrical surge damaged the computer's disk drive.
The National Grid was hit by a huge power surge.

senses.definition: to move quickly and with force in a particular direction

examples.x: The gates opened and the crowd surged forward.
Flood waters surged into their homes.
He surged past the other runners on the last lap.

senses.definition: to fill somebody with a strong feeling

examples.x: Relief surged through her.

senses.definition: to suddenly increase in value

examples.x: Share prices surged.

senses.definition: to increase suddenly
a change that somebody/something causes in somebody/something else; a result One consequence of

examples.x: the beneficial effects of exercise
What are the long-term effects of this treatment?
The results show a statistically significant effect.
Her tears had no effect on him.
the effect of heat on metal
Modern farming methods can have an adverse effect on the environment.
Farms can have both positive and negative effects on the community.
Despite her ordeal, she seems to have suffered no ill effects.
The study examines architecture and its effect upon people's lives.
to examine/study/investigate the effect of something
to evaluate/assess the effect of something
to cause harmful health effects
I can certainly feel the effects of too many late nights.
Her criticisms had the effect of discouraging him completely.
to learn to distinguish between cause and effect
I tried to persuade him, but with little or no effect.
‘I'm feeling really depressed.’ ‘The winter here has that effect sometimes.’

senses.definition: a particular look, sound or impression that somebody, such as an artist or a writer, wants to create

examples.x: The overall effect of the painting is overwhelming.
The stage lighting gives the effect of a moonlit scene.
She uses glass to achieve a variety of visual effects.
to produce/create an effect
Add a scarf for a casual effect.
He only behaves like that for effect (= in order to impress people).

senses.definition: lights, sounds, special scenery, computer images, etc. used in a play or film, especially in order to show things that do not normally exist or happen

examples.x: The production relied too much on spectacular effects.

senses.definition: your personal possessions

examples.x: The insurance policy covers all baggage and personal effects.

senses.definition: used to introduce the result of the action or situation mentioned Thereby

examples.x: Regular exercise strengthens the heart, thereby reducing the risk of heart attack.

senses.definition: used to introduce the logical result of something that has just been mentioned therefore

examples.x: He's only 17 and therefore not eligible to vote.
There is still much to discuss. We shall, therefore, return to this item at our next meeting.

senses.definition: in the place, object, document, etc. mentioned

examples.x: The insurance policy covers the building and any fixtures contained therein.
In court she denied any knowledge of the article and the allegations made therein.

senses.definition: immediately after the situation mentioned; as a direct result of the situation mentioned

examples.x: The audience thereupon rose cheering to their feet.

senses.definition: on the thing mentioned

examples.x: a large notice with black letters printed thereupon

senses.definition: in this way; like this

examples.x: Many scholars have argued thus.
The universities have expanded, thus allowing many more people the chance of higher education.
She rarely gave interviews and thus avoided being asked questions she would rather not answer.

senses.definition: as a result of something just mentioned therefore

examples.x: He is the eldest son and thus heir to the title.
We do not own the building. Thus, it would be impossible for us to make any major changes to it.

senses.definition: a general direction in which a situation is changing or developing fell significantly

examples.x: social/economic/political/demographic trends
fashion/market trends
There is a growing trend towards later retirement.
The article discusses current trends in language teaching
This downward trend in sales is likely to continue.
There has been an upward trend in the number of accidents reported.
Predicting long-term trends in consumer behaviour is more difficult.
A trend for romance and nostalgia has emerged.

examples.cf: trend for somebody/something to do something
examples.x: There is an increasing trend for students to live at home.
You seem to have set (= started) a new trend.
This trend is being reversed (= is going in the opposite direction).
One region is attempting to buck (= oppose or resist) the trend of economic decline.
Inflation continued its downward trend last month.
Regional growth figures are following the national trend.
The number of visitors to the city is showing an upward trend.
The underlying trend of inflation is still upwards.
If this trend continues, the species could soon become extinct.
Linen is on trend (= fashionable) again this summer.

senses.definition: to make something happen suddenly

examples.x: Nuts can trigger off a violent allergic reaction.
The incident triggered protests across the country.

senses.definition: to cause a device to start functioning

examples.x: to trigger an alarm

senses.definition: to make somebody feel very upset or anxious by reminding them of a trauma or bad experience

examples.x: Sometimes, the slightest things trigger me because they remind me of my mum.

senses.definition: the part of a gun that you press in order to fire it

examples.x: to pull/squeeze the trigger
He kept his finger on the trigger.

senses.definition: something that is the cause of a particular reaction or development, especially a bad one

examples.x: The trigger for the strike was the closure of yet another factory.
When dealing with panic attacks it's important to understand your triggers.
Intense sunlight may be a trigger to skin cancer.
a radical plan that would have served as a trigger to create chaos in the country

senses.definition: to be the basis or cause of something Underlie

examples.x: These ideas underlie much of his work.
It is a principle that underlies all the party's policies.

senses.definition: the final result of a series of events

examples.x: The upshot of it all was that he left college and got a job.

senses.definition: a sudden large increase in something

examples.x: an upsurge in violent crime
a recent upsurge of interest in his movies

senses.definition: a situation in which something improves or increases over a period of time

examples.x: an upswing in economic activity
an upswing in the team’s fortunes

senses.definition: a situation in which something improves or increases over a period of time

examples.x: an upturn in the economy
a sharp upturn in the number of tourists visiting the capital
Their fortunes have taken an upturn.
The restaurant trade is on the upturn.

senses.definition: pointing towards or facing a higher place

examples.x: an upward gaze
Any expansion would have to be upward.

senses.definition: increasing in amount or price

examples.x: an upward movement in property prices
an upward trend in the rate of unemployment
The long-term trend in foreign direct investment is upward.

senses.definition: towards a higher place or position

examples.x: Place your hands on the table with the palms facing upwards.
We were moving upwards at an incredible speed.
A flight of steps led upwards to the front door.
He was pointing upwards at the roof.
The corners of her mouth curved upwards in amusement.

senses.definition: towards a higher amount or price

examples.x: Bad weather forced the price of fruit upwards.
The budget has been revised upwards.

senses.definition: more than the amount or number mentioned

examples.x: You should expect to pay upwards of £50 for a hotel room.

senses.definition: by which; because of which

examples.x: They have introduced a new system whereby all employees must undergo regular training.

senses.definition: and then; as a result of this

examples.x: He told her she was a liar, whereupon she walked out.

senses.definition: because
